contentrichtext.text: {{About|the body of water|the battle|Battle of Leyte Gulf}} [[File:US Navy 060221-N-5067K-190 A Landing Craft Air Cushioned (LCAC) assigned to Assault Craft Unit Five (ACU-5) embarked aboard the amphibious assault ship USS Essex (LHD 2) heads to the island of Leyte.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Leyte Gulf near Guinsahugon ]] '''Leyte Gulf''' is a body of water immediately east of the [[island]] of [[Leyte (island)|Leyte]] in the [[Philippines]], adjoining the [[Philippine Sea]] of the [[Pacific Ocean]], at {{coord|10|50|N|125|25|E|display=inline,title}}. The [[Bay|Gulf]] is bounded on the north by the island of [[Samar (island)|Samar]], which is separated from Leyte on the west by the narrow [[San Juanico Strait]], and on the south by [[Mindanao]], separated from Leyte by the [[Surigao Strait]].<ref name="geography" /> [[Dinagat Island]] partly encloses the Gulf to the southeast, and the small [[Homonhon Island]] and [[Suluan Island]], sit astride the eastern entrance to the Gulf. It is approximately 130 km (80 mi) north-south, and 60 km (40 mi) east-west.<ref name="geography">{{cite book|last=Woodward|first=C. Vann|coauthors=Evan Thomas|title=The Battle for Leyte Gulf: The Incredible Story of World War II's Largest Naval Battle|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc|date=1997|pages=3â€“7|isbn=1-60239-194-7}}</ref> Leyte Gulf was also the scene of the [[Battle of Leyte Gulf|largest naval battle]] of the [[Second World War]]. Once captured by the Allies, the islands in the Gulf became bases for the [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress|B-29]]'s that bombed Japan in 1945.<ref name="geography" /> ==Notes== {{reflist}}{{Commons category}} [[Category:Gulfs of the Philippines]] {{Philippines-geo-stub}} {{List of Philippine seas}}
